ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Particularly for a first run, this course was well thought through and implemented. We've thoroughly evaluated the course with recommendations for next year during the course itself, so I'm not going to repeat my impressions, but I appreciated that Gordon and the team welcomed so much dialogue and evaluation of what went well and what could be improved.
The workload could be greater in the beginning and middle of the semester.
The class was rough around the edges because it was its first year, but I think it will improve in following years.
Question 10: This course is very valuable to students interested in global public health.
Great course! Gordon was an incredible professor and I look forward to the continuation of the course.
Q4. The workload was heavier considering that we needed to devote entire spring break for it. But then it never felt like work!!!

I thought the trip was excellent, but I think it could have been better planned. If we had been able to connect with the hospital earlier and talk about the schedule for the trip, we would have been able to schedule more things related to our projects and gotten more valuable research accomplished.
The field trip; Murray's lecture and the visit from the Clinton crew.
The course material and the professor were amazing.
My fellow students, Jared and Jason, and Gordon. By far, the people made this a wonderful class.
On site evaluation/experience. autonomy and respectfriendly environment
the trip to Haiti
I enjoyed the field trip and gained lots of on the ground knowledge from the trip. Also, it's a great course to share the knowledge among the groups.
It was great to have a class with such a practical approach.
The field trip to Haiti was the most educational part of the course.
Interactive learning and the iterative process of the course.

1. Gordon and Gary; Jason and Jared; All the classmates - very good initial screening!2. The trip to Haiti3. The flexibility given to students on the projects4. The opportunity to contribute to a real world sustainable development effort5. The parties at Gary's and Gordon's6. The experience of working with different schools at Yale7. The HAS hosts and the wonderful place we stayed at8. The sincere efforts of Met Lemothe to teach us Creole9. Gordon's motherly concern for everyone and even chaperoning one student through the immigration process10.
This is one of the best classes that I have taken at Yale. The readings, speakers, and coursework wereall extremely well-chosen. Thanks for putting such thoughtful effort into setting this up!
Learning about a wide array of issues relevant to health and environmental sustainability in Haiti. Learning how to ask the right questions specific to a certain site.
The chance to visit Haiti, learn a lot about the country, and perhaps contribute something valuable to a very impressive group working there.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Helping provide more tools initially that help individuals do project design and project evaluation.
Nothing, this class is currently in a state of formation and reformation, it was perfect for what it was and what it will become.
specific goal organization which we worked throughout the course
it should be taught / co-lead by a development practitioner.
I feel there was an over emphasis on agroforestry. At times it seemed like the other projects were much less important.
If possible, deadlines and intermediate goals/assignments should be clearly outlined at the beginning of the semester. Communication between teams and between HAS and teams could be improved.
1. Learning Creole a bit earlier and more in detail2. More time in Haiti3. A couple of class lectures - like the one on project management
Focus and direction.

The class should definitely talk about what "sustainable development" is first and then move on to setting goals and coming up with projects. Without everyone being on the same page about what the goals of a "development" project should be first, it's very hard to work on a project proposal. Also, Haiti in general and the culture and people of the Artibonite Valley were two very important areas that should have been covered much more in depth. While the talks from outside people were very useful, I felt basic information was dropped to include them.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Excellent. Jared&Jason both were tremendously helpful and available to the teams.
Both amazing.
very good. responded to every question and helpful, approachable
Both were helpful and responsive
The TAs are extremely helpful and responsive.
Awesome, all was awesome.
JB: incredibly helpful in coordinating agendas in Haiti.
Always very helpful
All four of them very just perfect in their own style. Caring, friendly and ready to help whenever required.
Both Jared and Jason were absolutely great!
Amazing TAs and very supportive instructor.
Excellent. All were incredibly available.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: First exposure to agroforestry training that I've ever had, as well as rapid assessment. Practical tools learned.
I've sent very detailed feedback to the instructor for all the questions here. Please, refer to those comments =)
I am interested in sustainable development and this course allowed me the opportunity of working on a live project.

This was an elective course for me that greatly expanded my understanding of the history and current development efforts going on in Haiti. I found it very helpful for framing how I think about development in general, both domestically and abroad.
My background and interest is in economic development and this was very helpful as a panorama of various issues that affect development in the area.
I thought of it as a course giving practical experience in the field of sustainable development.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn how people design development initiatives and do interviews to generate an overview of a region and a problem with very little background experience and potentially no language skills.
A thorough understanding of the processes and setbacks involved in evaluating, designing, implementing, and improving health and technology interventions in the developing world context.
an interest in development work.
I've always interested in sustainable development in the mid- or low-income countries and this course provides a great opportunity to explore more in-depth knowledge within a specific country.
I took this course to learn about Haiti and international development. This course was an practical opportunity to apply coursework to real world problems.
Hands on experience and a desire to get involved in on the ground work in Haiti
For pratical experience working on sustainable development.

I had been to Haiti in January and was very interested in learning more about the forces that made it what it is today, as well as what kind of measures have been shown to be effective in improving conditions in places such as Haiti.
To study Haiti

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, some understandable disorganization being the first time class was being run, but overall a great class. I love any class that brings to students experience in applied knowledge.
yes.
Absolutely.
It's very good, even better than I expected.
YES!
Yes.
Yes
Exceeded.
yes!
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
yes.

I don't feel like I learned as much about sustainable development as I thought I would. Perhaps a couple classes during the semester that frame the class's activities in terms of development theory would be helpful.
Yes, Gordon, Gary, the TAs and the lecturers are extremely nice and helpful.
Yes, I got more out of it than I expected.
I certainly got more out of this experience than I contributed to HAS or to Haiti. This course helped me understand the challenges of development work.
Yes
Absolutely!
definitely.
Yes
I would have liked more guidance on appropriate and effective ways to do international consultant work in sustainable development.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Not entirely happy with the work group. Feel like work should have been more evenly distributed between team members, but there is nothing the instructor could have done.

Advantages: their expertise in areas I lacked expertise in; disadvantages: very different working and communication styles and a lack of convergence in evaluation for our client--I saw things very differently from team members that sometimes chose not to deliver the product to our client that our client had requested, whether because the students were uninterested, or thought it was un-strategic, it was sometimes unclear.
We had a very good team, cooperative and brilliant ideas
great to be able to focus on a topic.
By brainstorming, we get a veriety of ideas which contribute to our projects better.
You got to know your group members very well and work with people with varied interests.
1. Diverse thinking2. Improving our ideas3. Help with logistics and co-ordination
Really great time to interact with and learn from other students. Helped me feel more engaged with the course and I got good feedback from them.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be fully committed to the course and its mission. This class should be a priority and should not represent just a grade or an 'easy A'.

Enroll if you speak French or Creole; you will get much more out of the course than if you only speak English. Seek outside support from experts in the field you're assigned to/volunteer for, in terms of projects--you will not get all of the training and advice you need within the course. However, that's the point--you're building a team to consult on a semi-unfamiliar issue and you will need to marshall external resources to do so.
It would be great if they have an idea of what kind of projects they would like to work on and how at the very beginning. It might also helpful to collaborate with other groups.
Take initiative.
Speak with former students and initiate a dialog with HAS early on. Before traveling to Haiti, clearly articulate your aims for the trip to HAS.
Congratulations! Its an opportunity to do something meaningful, make the most of it.
It will change next year and I plan to offer advice then...
